moves.3. Bb5: A bit like a Canal- Sokolsky( Nimzovich-Rossolimo) attack but with e6.
moves.3... a6: Kicks the bishop to either c4, d3 e2 or f1.
moves.5. O-O Be7 6. c3: White tries to occupy the centre with two centre pawns. Next move he will strike the centre unless I strike it first.
moves.6... d5 7. exd5 exd5 8. d4 c4: I advance as White can't attack from the flanks.
moves.9. Re1 Nf6 10. Bg5 h6: I should've castled here but h6 was a natural response which ended in me being a pawn down.
moves.11. Bxf6: Taking with the pawn would leave my king unsafe.
moves.15... g6: Blocking the mate and creating a nice square for my DSB.
White's position is far better and White should've played slowly holding on to his extra pawn and more comfortable position. But instead white attempts to crash through quickly.
moves.26. Rxh5 Nxd4: The best response. I will be up an exchange here but white will  have an extra pawn.
moves.27. Nxd4 gxh5 28. Re3 Bxe5: Wasting whites tempo but giving up my important DSB.
moves.30. Ne6: Ne6?? I'm up a rook for a knight and pawn. This sac was unneccesary. It was to open lines for the queen.
Threaten mate and tries to trade off queens.
moves.39. Qh3: Keeping the queens on the boards and protecting g3.
moves.39... e5: I am able to advance freely as is Rxe5 fails to Qb1+
